_link.title: I can interpret a binding energy curve to compare nuclear stability

toLevel2.question: What is binding energy?
options: The energy needed to split a nucleus into individual nucleons
The energy released when a nucleus forms
The energy stored in electron orbitals
toLevel2.correct: The energy needed to split a nucleus into individual nucleons
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Binding energy is the amount of energy required to completely separate a nucleus into its component protons and neutrons.

distractorExplanations.The energy released when a nucleus forms: This describes the same quantity from the opposite perspective, but binding energy is defined as energy required for separation.
distractorExplanations.The energy stored in electron orbitals: Electron binding energy is different from nuclear binding energy.
distractorExplanations.The kinetic energy of protons: Kinetic energy is energy of motion, not nuclear binding.

toLevel2.question: Which element has the highest binding energy per nucleon?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Iron-56 sits at the peak of the binding energy curve with about 8.8 MeV per nucleon, making it the most tightly bound nucleus.

distractorExplanations.Hydrogen (H-1): Hydrogen-1 has no binding energy (single nucleon) and is at the start of the curve.
distractorExplanations.Uranium (U-238): Uranium has lower binding energy per nucleon (~7.6 MeV) than iron.
distractorExplanations.Helium (He-4): Helium-4 has high binding energy (~7 MeV) but not as high as iron.

toLevel2.question: What does a higher binding energy per nucleon indicate about a nucleus?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Higher binding energy per nucleon means more energy is required to break apart the nucleus, indicating greater stability.

distractorExplanations.Less stability: Higher binding energy means the nucleus is harder to break apart, so more stable.
distractorExplanations.More radioactivity: Stable nuclei with high binding energy are typically less radioactive.
distractorExplanations.Larger size: Binding energy per nucleon doesn't directly correlate with nuclear size.

toLevel2.question: What is the approximate binding energy per nucleon for iron-56?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Iron-56 has the highest binding energy per nucleon at approximately 8.8 MeV.

distractorExplanations.1.1 MeV: This is much too low; 1.1 MeV is around the binding energy of deuterium.
distractorExplanations.7.6 MeV: This is approximately the binding energy per nucleon for uranium, not iron.
distractorExplanations.0 MeV: Zero binding energy would mean no nuclear binding at all.

toLevel2.question: On a binding energy curve, what is plotted on the y-axis?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The binding energy curve plots binding energy per nucleon (in MeV) against mass number to compare stability across different nuclei.

distractorExplanations.Total binding energy: Total binding energy would increase continuously with mass number, hiding the stability pattern.
distractorExplanations.Mass number: Mass number is plotted on the x-axis, not y-axis.
distractorExplanations.Atomic number: Atomic number is not what's plotted on the binding energy curve.

toLevel2.question: The binding energy per nucleon reaches its maximum around {{c1::iron-56}}.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Iron-56 sits at the peak of the binding energy curve, representing the most stable nuclear configuration.

toLevel2.question: Binding energy is the energy needed to {{c1::split}} a nucleus into individual nucleons.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Binding energy measures how strongly nucleons are held together, which equals the energy required to separate them.

toLevel2.question: A nucleus with higher binding energy per nucleon is more {{c1::stable}}.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Greater binding energy means nucleons are held more tightly, making the nucleus harder to disrupt.

toLevel2.question: Uranium-238 has a higher binding energy per nucleon than iron-56.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Iron-56 has the highest binding energy per nucleon (~8.8 MeV). Uranium-238 has about 7.6 MeV per nucleon.

toLevel2.question: The binding energy curve shows that iron-56 is the most stable nucleus.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The peak of the binding energy curve at iron-56 indicates maximum stability - nucleons are most tightly bound.

toLevel3.question: Why does the binding energy curve explain that both fusion and fission can release energy?
options: Both processes move toward iron-56, which has maximum binding energy per nucleon
Energy is always released in nuclear reactions
The curve is flat, so all nuclei have equal energy
toLevel3.correct: Both processes move toward iron-56, which has maximum binding energy per nucleon
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Fusion of light nuclei and fission of heavy nuclei both produce products closer to iron-56, where binding energy per nucleon is higher, releasing the difference as energy.

distractorExplanations.Both processes create hydrogen: Neither fusion nor fission necessarily creates hydrogen; they move toward iron.
distractorExplanations.Energy is always released in nuclear rea: Only reactions moving toward higher binding energy release energy.
distractorExplanations.The curve is flat, so all nuclei have eq: The curve peaks at iron, showing variation in stability.

toLevel3.question: Why does fission of uranium release energy?
options: The fission products have higher binding energy per nucleon than uranium
Uranium has the highest binding energy
Fission products are heavier than uranium
toLevel3.correct: The fission products have higher binding energy per nucleon than uranium
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Uranium (~7.6 MeV/nucleon) splits into products closer to iron on the binding energy curve (~8.5 MeV/nucleon), releasing the difference.

distractorExplanations.Uranium has the highest binding energy: Iron has the highest; uranium is lower on the curve.
distractorExplanations.Fission products are heavier than uraniu: Fission products are lighter than the original uranium nucleus.
distractorExplanations.Energy is created from nothing: Energy comes from the mass difference (E=mc²), not from nothing.

toLevel3.question: Why does fusing hydrogen into helium release energy?
options: Helium has higher binding energy per nucleon than hydrogen
Hydrogen is more stable than helium
Energy is absorbed from the surroundings
toLevel3.correct: Helium has higher binding energy per nucleon than hydrogen
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Hydrogen nuclei combining into helium move up the binding energy curve, with the binding energy difference released as energy.

distractorExplanations.Hydrogen is more stable than helium: Helium is more stable with higher binding energy per nucleon.
distractorExplanations.The mass increases during fusion: Mass actually decreases; the lost mass becomes energy.
distractorExplanations.Energy is absorbed from the surroundings: Fusion releases energy; the products have less total mass.

toLevel3.question: Why is it impossible to release energy by fusing iron nuclei?
options: Iron is at the peak of the binding energy curve; any change decreases binding energy
Iron is too small for fusion
toLevel3.correct: Iron is at the peak of the binding energy curve; any change decreases binding energy
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Since iron has maximum binding energy per nucleon, any nuclear reaction would produce less stable products, requiring energy input rather than releasing it.

distractorExplanations.Iron cannot undergo nuclear reactions: Iron can undergo nuclear reactions, they just require energy rather than release it.
distractorExplanations.Iron is too small for fusion: Size isn't the issue; it's that fusion products would have lower binding energy.

toLevel3.question: What happens to binding energy per nucleon as you move from helium to iron on the curve?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Moving from light nuclei toward iron, binding energy per nucleon increases, reaching maximum at iron.

distractorExplanations.It decreases: Binding energy increases toward iron, then decreases for heavier nuclei.
distractorExplanations.It stays constant: The whole point of the curve is that binding energy varies with mass number.
distractorExplanations.It becomes negative: Binding energy is always positive for bound nuclei.

toLevel3.question: Nuclear fusion releases energy because the products have {{c1::higher}} binding energy per nucleon than the reactants.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Moving up the binding energy curve (toward iron) releases the energy difference between initial and final binding energies.

toLevel3.question: Both fusion and fission release energy because they both produce products closer to {{c1::iron-56}} on the binding energy curve.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Iron-56 represents the most stable nuclear configuration; moving toward it from either direction releases energy.

toLevel3.question: The energy released in nuclear reactions comes from the {{c1::mass}} difference between reactants and products.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: According to E=mc², the mass difference is converted to energy when binding energy changes.

toLevel3.question: Fusing nuclei heavier than iron would release energy.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Nuclei heavier than iron have lower binding energy per nucleon than iron, so fusion would require energy input, not release it.

toLevel3.question: The binding energy curve explains why stars eventually produce iron in their cores.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Stars fuse lighter elements into heavier ones, releasing energy until they reach iron, where fusion no longer releases energy.

toLevel4.question: If uranium-238 (binding energy 7.6 MeV/nucleon) undergoes fission into two nuclei with 8.5 MeV/nucleon binding energy, approximately how much energy is released per nucleon?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Energy released per nucleon = 8.5 - 7.6 = 0.9 MeV. The products are more tightly bound by this amount.

distractorExplanations.8.5 MeV: This is the binding energy of products, not the energy released.
distractorExplanations.7.6 MeV: This is the initial binding energy, not the change.
distractorExplanations.16.1 MeV: This would be the sum, but energy released is the difference.

toLevel4.question: Deuterium (2.2 MeV/nucleon) and tritium (2.8 MeV/nucleon) fuse to form helium-4 (7.1 MeV/nucleon) plus a neutron. Why is significant energy released?
options: The product helium has much higher binding energy per nucleon
toLevel4.correct: The product helium has much higher binding energy per nucleon
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Moving from ~2.5 MeV/nucleon average to 7.1 MeV/nucleon represents a large increase in binding energy, releasing the difference.

distractorExplanations.The reactants are destroyed completely: Nucleons are conserved; they're rearranged, not destroyed.
distractorExplanations.Neutrons carry no binding energy: The neutron does affect energy balance, but the main release is from increased binding.
distractorExplanations.The total mass increases: Mass decreases; the lost mass becomes energy.

toLevel4.question: A nucleus has a total binding energy of 500 MeV and contains 60 nucleons. What is its binding energy per nucleon?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Binding energy per nucleon = Total binding energy / Number of nucleons = 500/60 = 8.33 MeV.

distractorExplanations.500 MeV: This is the total binding energy, not per nucleon.
distractorExplanations.60 MeV: This is the number of nucleons, not an energy.
distractorExplanations.30000 MeV: This would be 500 × 60, which is not how it's calculated.

toLevel4.question: On the binding energy curve, helium-4 appears as a local peak above its neighbours. What does this indicate?
options: Helium-4 is unusually stable for its mass number
Helium-4 is less stable than lithium
toLevel4.correct: Helium-4 is unusually stable for its mass number
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Helium-4's peak indicates it is exceptionally tightly bound, which is why alpha particles (He-4 nuclei) are commonly emitted in radioactive decay.

distractorExplanations.Helium-4 is less stable than lithium: The peak shows helium-4 is MORE stable than nearby nuclei.
distractorExplanations.The curve has errors: The peak is a real physical effect due to helium-4's structure.
distractorExplanations.Helium has too many neutrons: He-4 has a balanced 2 protons and 2 neutrons.

toLevel4.question: Why does the binding energy per nucleon decrease for nuclei heavier than iron?
options: Electrostatic repulsion between protons increasingly overcomes strong force binding
Heavy nuclei have too many electrons
The strong force gets weaker in heavy nuclei
toLevel4.correct: Electrostatic repulsion between protons increasingly overcomes strong force binding
toLevel4.correctExplanation: As nuclei grow larger, the long-range electrostatic repulsion between protons reduces the net binding, while the short-range strong force saturates.

distractorExplanations.Heavy nuclei have too many electrons: Electrons don't affect nuclear binding energy.
distractorExplanations.The strong force gets weaker in heavy nu: The force itself doesn't weaken; it's the balance with electrostatic repulsion that changes.
distractorExplanations.Heavy nuclei have no neutrons: Heavy nuclei have many neutrons, but they can't fully compensate for proton repulsion.

toLevel4.question: For U-235 fission releasing 200 MeV total energy with 235 nucleons, the energy released per nucleon is approximately {{c1::0.85}} MeV.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Energy per nucleon = 200 MeV / 235 nucleons ≈ 0.85 MeV per nucleon.

toLevel4.question: The decrease in binding energy per nucleon for nuclei heavier than iron is due to increasing {{c1::electrostatic repulsion}} between protons.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: As proton count increases, the long-range repulsive force increasingly counteracts the short-range strong force binding.

toLevel4.question: Helium-4 appears as a local {{c1::peak}} on the binding energy curve, indicating exceptional stability.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: This local maximum shows helium-4 is more tightly bound than nearby nuclei, explaining why it's emitted as a unit in alpha decay.

toLevel4.question: If a nuclear reaction increases the total binding energy of the system, energy will be released.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Increased binding energy means tighter binding; the energy difference is released, typically as kinetic energy and radiation.

toLevel4.question: The binding energy curve predicts that iron could be fused or fissioned to release energy.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Iron is at the peak; any nuclear reaction on iron would produce less stable products, requiring energy input.

toLevel5.question: In stellar nucleosynthesis, why do massive stars develop iron cores that cannot sustain fusion?
options: Iron fusion would consume energy rather than release it, removing the pressure support against gravity
Iron is too heavy to fuse
Stars run out of fuel before reaching iron
toLevel5.correct: Iron fusion would consume energy rather than release it, removing the pressure support against gravity
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Since iron is at the binding energy peak, fusing it absorbs energy. Without energy release, the star cannot support itself and undergoes core collapse.

distractorExplanations.Iron is too heavy to fuse: Iron can fuse given enough energy, but it absorbs rather than releases energy.
distractorExplanations.Stars run out of fuel before reaching ir: Massive stars do produce iron; that's precisely the problem.
distractorExplanations.Iron reflects all radiation: This has no relevance to nuclear fusion processes.

toLevel5.question: The semi-empirical mass formula approximates binding energy with terms for volume, surface, Coulomb, asymmetry, and pairing effects. What does the Coulomb term represent?
options: The reduction in binding due to proton-proton electrostatic repulsion
The increase in binding from neutrons
toLevel5.correct: The reduction in binding due to proton-proton electrostatic repulsion
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The Coulomb term is negative (reduces binding) and accounts for electrostatic repulsion between protons, proportional to Z(Z-1)/A^(1/3).

distractorExplanations.The increase in binding from neutrons: Neutrons contribute through volume and asymmetry terms, not Coulomb.
distractorExplanations.The energy from electron shells: The formula addresses nuclear binding, not atomic electrons.
distractorExplanations.The strong force contribution: Strong force binding is primarily in the volume term.

toLevel5.question: Why does the binding energy curve show that nickel-62 actually has slightly higher binding energy per nucleon than iron-56?
options: Ni-62 has optimal proton-neutron balance and shell effects that slightly exceed Fe-56
Iron is less stable than claimed
Nickel has fewer protons than iron
toLevel5.correct: Ni-62 has optimal proton-neutron balance and shell effects that slightly exceed Fe-56
toLevel5.correctExplanation: While Fe-56 is often cited, Ni-62 has marginally higher binding energy per nucleon due to nuclear shell effects and optimal nucleon ratio.

distractorExplanations.The curve is incorrectly drawn: The measurements are accurate; Fe-56 is often used as a convenient approximation.
distractorExplanations.Iron is less stable than claimed: Fe-56 is still extremely stable, just marginally below Ni-62.
distractorExplanations.Nickel has fewer protons than iron: Nickel (Z=28) has more protons than iron (Z=26).

toLevel5.question: In nucleosynthesis, elements heavier than iron are primarily formed by what process?
options: Neutron capture followed by beta decay (r-process and s-process)
toLevel5.correct: Neutron capture followed by beta decay (r-process and s-process)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Since fusion beyond iron absorbs energy, heavy elements form via neutron capture, building mass without the energy cost of overcoming Coulomb barriers.

distractorExplanations.Fusion in stellar cores: Fusion releases energy only up to iron; heavier elements require other mechanisms.
distractorExplanations.Fission of super-heavy elements: While some fission occurs, neutron capture builds most heavy elements.
distractorExplanations.Electron capture only: Electron capture is involved but neutron capture is the primary mass-building mechanism.

toLevel5.question: The binding energy difference between reactants and products in nuclear reactions relates to mass through what principle?
options: E = mc²; the mass defect equals the binding energy divided by c²
toLevel5.correct: E = mc²; the mass defect equals the binding energy divided by c²
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The mass of a nucleus is less than the sum of its constituents by an amount (mass defect) that corresponds to the binding energy via Einstein's equation.

distractorExplanations.Conservation of momentum: Momentum conservation applies but doesn't explain the mass-energy relationship.
distractorExplanations.The uncertainty principle: This governs quantum measurements, not mass-energy equivalence.
distractorExplanations.Pauli exclusion: This affects nuclear structure but not the mass-energy relationship directly.

toLevel5.question: In supernovae, elements heavier than iron are created primarily through rapid {{c1::neutron capture}} (r-process).
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The r-process rapidly adds neutrons faster than beta decay, building heavy nuclei that later decay to stable isotopes.

toLevel5.question: The mass of a nucleus is {{c1::less}} than the sum of its constituent nucleon masses due to binding energy.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The 'missing' mass (mass defect) has been converted to binding energy according to E=mc².

toLevel5.question: The pairing term in the semi-empirical mass formula explains why nuclei with {{c1::even}} numbers of protons and neutrons are more stable.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Paired nucleons have lower energy states, making even-even nuclei more tightly bound than odd configurations.

toLevel5.question: The mass defect of a nucleus can be directly measured and equals the binding energy divided by c².
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Mass spectrometry can measure nuclear masses precisely, and the mass defect Δm relates to binding energy by E_b = Δm × c².

toLevel5.question: Core-collapse supernovae occur because iron cores can release energy through fusion to support the star.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Iron fusion absorbs energy (endothermic), so the core cannot generate pressure to resist gravity, leading to collapse.
